channel.title: AI Security Digest
channel.description: Curated AI security insights and articles from various sources

item.title: Build It Before Breaking It !!
item.description:
ðŸ“„ Source: WaterBucket Blog
ðŸ‘¤ Author: WaterBucket | ðŸ“… Date: 17-09-2023
Cybersecurity Active Directory Penetration Testing
This article introduces the first post in a series about creating an Active Directory home lab for red teamers, focusing on setting up and exploiting common misconfigurations. It provides step-by-step instructions to create vulnerable user accounts for attacks such as ASREP Roasting, Kerberoasting, and DC Sync using Windows Server 2019 and Kali Linux. The goal is to help readers understand and practice these attacks safely in a controlled environment.

item.title: Build it Before Breaking it !! â€” PART 2
item.description:
ðŸ“„ Source: WaterBucket Blog
ðŸ‘¤ Author: WaterBucket | ðŸ“… Date: 24-10-2023
Cybersecurity Active Directory Windows Server
This article provides a step-by-step guide on setting up an Unconstrained Delegation lab in a Windows Active Directory environment, including creating user and computer accounts and configuring delegation privileges. It also demonstrates how to verify the configuration using PowerShell and Impacket scripts, while deferring exploitation details to other resources. The next article will cover setting up Constrained Delegation.

item.title: Crafting Chaos: A deep dive into developing Shellcode Loaders!
item.description:
ðŸ“„ Source: WaterBucket Blog
ðŸ‘¤ Author: WaterBucket | ðŸ“… Date: 2024-03-24
Malware Development Shellcode Loading Network Programming
This article introduces a series focused on developing custom malware, specifically detailing the creation of a shellcode loader that downloads and executes shellcode from a remote server to evade static detection and bypass Microsoft Defender. It explains the technical implementation using Winsock2 for network communication and Early Bird APC Injection for process injection to execute the downloaded shellcode. The post provides a step-by-step guide on socket creation, connection, data reception, and the injection technique.

item.title: Uncovering 0-Days: The Crucial Role of RFCs in Vulnerability Research and the Recent Windows TCP/IPv6 Exploit
item.description:
ðŸ“„ Source: WaterBucket Blog
ðŸ‘¤ Author: WaterBucket | ðŸ“… Date: 2024-05-10
Cybersecurity Vulnerability Research Network Protocols
The article emphasizes the importance of understanding RFCs (Request for Comments) for vulnerability researchers, highlighting how these documents serve as foundational standards for internet protocols. It explains that deviations or misinterpretations of RFCs during implementation can lead to security vulnerabilities, illustrated by a recent critical exploit in Windows' tcpip.sys driver related to IPv6. The piece encourages researchers to study RFCs closely to identify potential 0-day vulnerabilities.

item.title: MS13â€“018: The TCP Bug That Made Windows Waitâ€¦ and Waitâ€¦ and Waitâ€¦
item.description:
ðŸ“„ Source: WaterBucket Blog
ðŸ‘¤ Author: WaterBucket | ðŸ“… Date: 2024-03-11
Cybersecurity Network Protocols Vulnerability Analysis
The article analyzes the MS13-018 vulnerability, a denial-of-service flaw in the Windows tcpip.sys driver affecting various Windows versions by exploiting how the TCP FIN_WAIT_2 state is handled. It explains the TCP connection teardown process, how the vulnerability allows attackers to exhaust system resources by forcing connections to remain open indefinitely, and discusses the importance of RFCs and patches in mitigating such issues. The author also shares a proof-of-concept exploit to deepen understanding of this N-day vulnerability.

item.title: Understanding IOCTLs for Windows Vulnerability Research & Exploit Development
item.description:
ðŸ“„ Source: WaterBucket Blog
ðŸ‘¤ Author: WaterBucket | ðŸ“… Date: 14-12-2024
Windows Security Vulnerability Research Exploit Development
The article provides an in-depth theoretical overview of IOCTLs (Input/Output Controls) in Windows, explaining their structure, interaction with IRPs, and role in driver communication. It serves as a foundational guide for vulnerability researchers and exploit developers interested in Windows driver reverse engineering, with a promise of a follow-up practical exploration focused on Elevation of Privilege (EoP) scenarios.

item.title: Understanding HalDispatchTable for Windows Vulnerability Research & Exploit Development
item.description:
ðŸ“„ Source: WaterBucket Blog
ðŸ‘¤ Author: WaterBucket | ðŸ“… Date: 2025-01-16
Windows Internals Kernel Vulnerability Research Exploit Development
This article delves into the HalDispatchTable within the Windows Hardware Abstraction Layer (HAL), explaining its role and significance in Windows kernel internals and historical exploit development. It highlights how hal.dll operates as a kernel-mode component abstracting hardware specifics to enable modular and portable Windows kernels across diverse hardware platforms. The post also touches on the HAL's responsibilities in system initialization and low-level hardware management.

item.title: Understanding Memory Descriptor Lists (MDLs) for Windows Vulnerability Research & Exploit Development
item.description:
ðŸ“„ Source: WaterBucket Blog
ðŸ‘¤ Author: WaterBucket | ðŸ“… Date: 2025-01-25
Windows Kernel Memory Management Security Exploits
The article explains Memory Descriptor Lists (MDLs) in the context of Windows vulnerability research, particularly relating to a kernel exploit involving the mskssrv.sys driver. It clarifies how MDLs map virtual memory to physical memory, enabling kernel-mode drivers to access user-mode buffers directly without costly memory copying, which is crucial for understanding certain logical vulnerabilities and exploit development.

item.title: Understanding Deferred Procedure Calls (DPCs) for Windows Vulnerability Research & Exploit Development
item.description:
ðŸ“„ Source: WaterBucket Blog
ðŸ‘¤ Author: WaterBucket | ðŸ“… Date: 2025-02-02
Windows Internals Operating System Security Vulnerability Research
This article explains Deferred Procedure Calls (DPCs) in Windows, a mechanism that defers lower-priority work to ensure fast and efficient interrupt handling by running at a specific Interrupt Request Level (IRQL). It also provides foundational knowledge on IRQLs and interrupt handling to help readers understand how Windows prioritizes tasks and manages system events. The author aims to clarify these niche Windows internals concepts for vulnerability research and exploit development.

item.title: Understanding Callback Registration Mechanisms in Windows
item.description:
ðŸ“„ Source: WaterBucket Blog
ðŸ‘¤ Author: WaterBucket | ðŸ“… Date: 2025-03-03
Windows Internals Kernel Programming Security Research
The article explores Windows callback registration mechanisms beyond common routines, detailing how kernel-mode components register callbacks to monitor system events like process creation and registry changes. It explains key registration functions such as ObRegisterCallbacks and CmRegisterCallbackEx, their internal data structures, and the use of altitude strings to prioritize callback execution. This insight is valuable for vulnerability research, exploit development, and understanding Windows internals.

item.title: Understanding Mini-Filter Drivers for Windows Vulnerability Research & Exploit Development
item.description:
ðŸ“„ Source: WaterBucket Blog
ðŸ‘¤ Author: WaterBucket | ðŸ“… Date: 2025-03-31
Windows Internals File System Drivers Kernel-Mode Programming
The article explores Mini-Filter Drivers within the Windows file system architecture, explaining their role in monitoring and modifying file system operations without interacting directly with lower-level drivers. It contrasts Mini-Filter Drivers with legacy filter drivers, detailing how they intercept I/O requests through the Filter Manager to provide controlled and isolated processing. The post also provides foundational knowledge on file system filter drivers, their operation with IRPs, and their significance in security and system management.

item.title: Understanding Path Resolution in Windows
item.description:
ðŸ“„ Source: WaterBucket Blog
ðŸ‘¤ Author: WaterBucket | ðŸ“… Date: 2025-07-20
Windows Internals Kernel Debugging Path Resolution
The article provides an in-depth exploration of Windows path resolution, focusing on the internal process that translates user-mode Win32 file paths into NT object namespace paths within the kernel. It explains the role of symbolic links, the ?? directory, and kernel structures involved in resolving paths, using tools like WinDbg to analyze these mechanisms for vulnerability research and exploit development.

item.title: Understanding System Prompts for AI Red-Teaming
item.description:
ðŸ“„ Source: WaterBucket Blog
ðŸ‘¤ Author: WaterBucket | ðŸ“… Date: 2025-09-21
AI Security Red-Teaming Agentic AI
The article explores the critical role of system prompts in agentic AI, detailing how they shape AI behavior, influence reasoning, and define the operational boundaries of sub-agents. It highlights the security risks posed by exposing system prompts during AI red-teaming and explains why protecting these prompts is essential for maintaining AI safety and integrity. The piece also discusses the dynamic and multi-agent nature of system prompts and their impact on AI session management.
